The **Commonwealth of Nations** , normally known as **the Commonwealth** ,[2]
is an [intergovernmental organisation](/wiki/Intergovernmental_organization
"Intergovernmental organization") of [53 member
states](/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations "Member states of
the Commonwealth of Nations") that are mostly former
[territories](/wiki/Territorial_evolution_of_the_British_Empire "Territorial
evolution of the British Empire") of the [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire
"British Empire").[3] The chief institutions of the organisation are the
[Commonwealth Secretariat](/wiki/Commonwealth_Secretariat "Commonwealth
Secretariat"), which focuses on intergovernmental aspects, and the
[Commonwealth Foundation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Foundation "Commonwealth
Foundation"), which focuses on non-governmental relations between member
states.[4]

The Commonwealth dates back to the first half of the 20th century with the
[decolonisation](/wiki/Decolonization "Decolonization") of the British Empire
through increased [self-governance](/wiki/Self-governance "Self-governance")
of its territories. It was originally created as the _British Commonwealth of
Nations_[5] through the [Balfour
Declaration](/wiki/Balfour_Declaration_of_1926 "Balfour Declaration of 1926")
at the [1926 Imperial Conference](/wiki/1926_Imperial_Conference "1926
Imperial Conference"), and formalised by the United Kingdom through the
[Statute of Westminster](/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931 "Statute of
Westminster 1931") in 1931. The current Commonwealth of Nations was formally
constituted by the [London Declaration](/wiki/London_Declaration "London
Declaration") in 1949, which modernised the community, and established the
member states as "free and equal".[6] The symbol of this free association is
[Queen Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II"), who is the [Head of
the Commonwealth](/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth "Head of the Commonwealth").
The Queen is [head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state") of 16 member
states, known as the [Commonwealth realms](/wiki/Commonwealth_realms
"Commonwealth realms"), while 32 other members are
[republics](/wiki/Republics_in_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations "Republics in the
Commonwealth of Nations") and five others have different monarchs.

Member states have no legal obligations to one another. Instead, they are
united by [language](/wiki/English_language "English language"), history,
culture and their shared values of [democracy](/wiki/Democracy "Democracy"),
[human rights](/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights") and the [rule of
law](/wiki/Rule_of_law "Rule of law").[4] These values are enshrined in the
[Commonwealth Charter](/wiki/Charter_of_the_Commonwealth "Charter of the
Commonwealth")[7] and promoted by the quadrennial [Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games").

The countries of the Commonwealth covers more than 29,958,050 km2 (11,566,870
sq mi), equivalent to 20% of the world's land area and spans all six inhabited
[continents](/wiki/Continent "Continent").

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: History")]

### Origins of the concept and establishment of the
term[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Origins of the concept and establishment of the term")]

Main articles: [British Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") and
[Historiography of the British
Empire](/wiki/Historiography_of_the_British_Empire "Historiography of the
British Empire")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/CommonwealthPrimeMinisters1944.jpg/220px-
CommonwealthPrimeMinisters1944.jpg)](/wiki/File:CommonwealthPrimeMinisters1944.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:CommonwealthPrimeMinisters1944.jpg "Enlarge")

The prime ministers of five members at the 1944 [Commonwealth Prime Ministers'
Conference](/wiki/Commonwealth_Prime_Ministers%27_Conference "Commonwealth
Prime Ministers' Conference"). (L-R) [Mackenzie King](/wiki/Mackenzie_King
"Mackenzie King") ([Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada")), [Jan
Smuts](/wiki/Jan_Smuts "Jan Smuts") ([South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South
Africa")), [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston Churchill")
([United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom")), [Peter
Fraser](/wiki/Peter_Fraser_\(New_Zealand_politician\) "Peter Fraser \(New
Zealand politician\)") ([New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand")) and
[John Curtin](/wiki/John_Curtin "John Curtin") ([Australia](/wiki/Australia
"Australia"))

[Queen Elizabeth II](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II"), in her
address to [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") on [Dominion Day](/wiki/Canada_Day
"Canada Day") in 1959, pointed out that the [confederation of
Canada](/wiki/Canadian_Confederation "Canadian Confederation") on 1 July 1867
had been the birth of the "first independent country within the British
Empire". She declared: "So, it also marks the beginning of that free
association of independent states which is now known as the Commonwealth of
Nations."[8] As long ago as 1884 [Lord
Rosebery](/wiki/Archibald_Primrose,_5th_Earl_of_Rosebery "Archibald Primrose,
5th Earl of Rosebery") had described, while visiting Australia, the changing
British Empire, as some of its colonies became more independent, as a
"Commonwealth of Nations".[9] Conferences of British and colonial prime
ministers occurred periodically from [the first one in
1887](/wiki/First_Colonial_Conference "First Colonial Conference"), leading to
the creation of the [Imperial Conferences](/wiki/Imperial_Conference "Imperial
Conference") in 1911.[10]

The Commonwealth developed from the imperial conferences. A specific proposal
was presented by [Jan Smuts](/wiki/Jan_Smuts "Jan Smuts") in 1917 when he
coined the term "the British Commonwealth of Nations" and envisioned the
"future constitutional relations and readjustments in essence" at the [Paris
Peace Conference of 1919](/wiki/Paris_Peace_Conference,_1919 "Paris Peace
Conference, 1919") by delegates from the Dominions as well as Britain.[11][12]
The term first received imperial statutory recognition in the [Anglo-Irish
Treaty](/wiki/Anglo-Irish_Treaty "Anglo-Irish Treaty") of 1921, when the term
_British Commonwealth of Nations_ was substituted for _British Empire_ in the
wording of the oath taken by members of parliament of the Irish Free
State.[13]

### Adoption and formalisation of the
Commonwealth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Adoption and formalisation of the Commonwealth")]

In the [Balfour Declaration](/wiki/Balfour_Declaration_of_1926 "Balfour
Declaration of 1926") at the [1926 Imperial
Conference](/wiki/1926_Imperial_Conference "1926 Imperial Conference"),
Britain and its dominions agreed they were "equal in status, in no way
subordinate one to another in any aspect of their domestic or external
affairs, though united by common allegiance to the Crown, and freely
associated as members of the British Commonwealth of Nations." The term
"[Commonwealth](/wiki/Commonwealth "Commonwealth")" was officially adopted to
describe the community.[14]

These aspects to the relationship were formalised by the [Statute of
Westminster](/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931 "Statute of Westminster 1931")
in 1931, which applied to [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") without the need for
ratification, but [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand"), and
[Newfoundland](/wiki/Dominion_of_Newfoundland "Dominion of Newfoundland") had
to ratify the statute for it to take effect. Newfoundland never did, as on 16
February 1934, with the consent of its parliament, the government of
Newfoundland voluntarily ended and governance reverted to direct control from
London. Newfoundland later joined Canada as its [10th
province](/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada "Provinces and territories
of Canada") in 1949.[15] Australia and New Zealand ratified the Statute in
[1942](/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_Adoption_Act_1942 "Statute of Westminster
Adoption Act 1942") and [1947](/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_Adoption_Act_1947
"Statute of Westminster Adoption Act 1947") respectively.[16][17]

Although the Union of South Africa was not among the Dominions that needed to
adopt the Statute of Westminster for it to take effect, two laws—the Status of
the Union Act, 1934, and the Royal Executive Functions and Seals Act of
1934—were passed to confirm South Africa's status as a sovereign state.[18]

### Decolonisation and self-
governance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Decolonisation and self-governance")]

Main article: [List of countries that have gained independence from the United
Kingdom](/wiki/List_of_countries_that_have_gained_independence_from_the_United_Kingdom
"List of countries that have gained independence from the United Kingdom")

After [World War II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II") ended, the British
Empire was gradually dismantled. Most of its components have become
independent countries, whether [Commonwealth realms](/wiki/Commonwealth_realms
"Commonwealth realms") or republics, and members of the Commonwealth. There
remain the 14 mainly self-governing [British overseas
territories](/wiki/British_overseas_territories "British overseas
territories") which retain some political association with the United Kingdom.
In April 1949, following the [London Declaration](/wiki/London_Declaration
"London Declaration"), the word "British" was dropped from the title of the
Commonwealth to reflect its changing nature.[19]

[Burma](/wiki/Burma "Burma") (also known as [Myanmar](/wiki/Myanmar
"Myanmar"), 1948) and [Aden](/wiki/Aden "Aden") (1967) are the only states
that were British colonies at the time of the war not to have joined the
Commonwealth upon independence. Former British
[protectorates](/wiki/Protectorate "Protectorate") and
[mandates](/wiki/League_of_Nations_mandate "League of Nations mandate") that
did not become members of the Commonwealth are [Egypt](/wiki/Egypt "Egypt")
(independent in 1922), [Iraq](/wiki/Iraq "Iraq") (1932),
[Transjordan](/wiki/Jordan "Jordan") (1946), [British
Palestine](/wiki/Mandatory_Palestine "Mandatory Palestine") (part of which
became the state of [Israel](/wiki/Israel "Israel") in 1948),
[Sudan](/wiki/Sudan "Sudan") (1956), [British
Somaliland](/wiki/British_Somaliland "British Somaliland") (which united with
the former [Italian Somaliland](/wiki/Italian_Somaliland "Italian Somaliland")
in 1960 to form the [Somali Republic](/wiki/Somali_Republic "Somali
Republic")), [Kuwait](/wiki/Kuwait "Kuwait") (1961), [Bahrain](/wiki/Bahrain
"Bahrain") (1971), [Oman](/wiki/Oman "Oman") (1971), [Qatar](/wiki/Qatar
"Qatar") (1971), and the [United Arab Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates
"United Arab Emirates") (1971).[20]

### Declining
roles[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Declining roles")]

The postwar Commonwealth was given a fresh mission by Queen Elizabeth in her
Christmas Day 1953 broadcast, where she envisioned the Commonwealth as "an
entirely new conception – built on the highest qualities of the Spirit of Man:
friendship, loyalty, and the desire for freedom and peace."[21] Hoped for
success was reinforced by such achievements as [climbing Mount Everest in
1953](/wiki/1953_British_Mount_Everest_expedition "1953 British Mount Everest
expedition"), [breaking the four minute mile](/wiki/Roger_Bannister "Roger
Bannister") in 1954, and in [1966 a solo circumnavigation of the
globe](/wiki/Francis_Chichester "Francis Chichester").[22] However, the
humiliation of the [Suez Crisis](/wiki/Suez_Crisis "Suez Crisis") of 1956
badly hurt morale of Britain and the Commonwealth as a whole. More broadly,
there was the loss of a central role of the British Empire: the defence of the
Empire. That role was no longer militarily or financially feasible, as
[Britain's withdrawal from Greece in 1947](/wiki/Truman_Doctrine "Truman
Doctrine") had painfully demonstrated. Britain itself was now just one part of
the [NATO](/wiki/NATO "NATO") military alliance in which the Commonwealth had
no role apart from Canada. The ANZUS treaty of 1955 linked Australia, New
Zealand, and the United States in a defensive alliance, with Britain and the
Commonwealth left out. The second major function of the Empire made London the
financial centre of the system. After the Second World War, the British
treasury was so weak that it could not operate independently of the United
States. The loss of defence and financial roles, furthermore, undermined
Joseph Chamberlain's early 20th century vision of a world empire that could
combine Imperial preference, mutual defence, and social growth arm.
Furthermore, Britain's cosmopolitan role in world affairs became increasingly
limited, especially with the losses of India and Singapore.[23] While British
elites at first hoped the Commonwealth would preserve and project British
influence, they gradually lost their enthusiasm, argues Krishnan Srinivasan.
Early enthusiasm waned as British policies came under fire in Commonwealth
meetings. Public opinion became troubled as immigration from non-white member
states became large-scale.[24]

###
Republics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Republics")]

On 18 April 1949, Ireland formally became a republic in accordance with the
Irish [Republic of Ireland Act 1948](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland_Act_1948
"Republic of Ireland Act 1948"). Because it did this, it was automatically
excluded from the Commonwealth. While Ireland had not actively participated in
the Commonwealth since the early 1930s and was content to leave the
Commonwealth, other dominions wished to become republics without losing
Commonwealth ties. The issue came to a head in April 1949 at a Commonwealth
prime ministers' meeting in London. Under the [London
Declaration](/wiki/London_Declaration "London Declaration"),
[India](/wiki/India "India") agreed that, when it became a republic in January
1950, it would accept the British Sovereign as a "symbol of the free
association of its independent member nations and as such the Head of the
Commonwealth". Upon hearing this, King [George VI](/wiki/George_VI "George
VI") told the Indian politician [Krishna Menon](/wiki/Krishna_Menon "Krishna
Menon"): "So, I've become 'as such'".[25] The other Commonwealth countries
recognised India's continuing membership of the association. At Pakistan's
insistence, India was not regarded as an exceptional case and it was assumed
that other states would be accorded the same treatment as India.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The London Declaration is often seen as marking the beginning of the modern
Commonwealth. Following India's precedent, other nations became
[republics](/wiki/Republic "Republic"), or [constitutional
monarchies](/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy "Constitutional monarchy") with
their own monarchs, while some countries retained the same monarch as the
United Kingdom, but their monarchies developed differently and soon became
fully independent of the British monarchy. The monarch is regarded as a
separate [legal personality](/wiki/Legal_personality "Legal personality") in
each realm, even though the same person is monarch of each realm.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### New
Commonwealth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: New Commonwealth")]

Planners in the interwar period, like [Lord
Davies](/wiki/David_Davies,_1st_Baron_Davies "David Davies, 1st Baron
Davies"), who had also taken "a prominent part in building up the League of
Nations Union" in the United Kingdom, in 1932 founded the [New Commonwealth
Society](/wiki/New_Commonwealth_Society "New Commonwealth Society"), of which
British section [Winston Churchill](/wiki/Winston_Churchill "Winston
Churchill") became the president.[26] This new society was aimed at the
creation of an international air force to be the arm of the [League of
Nations](/wiki/League_of_Nations "League of Nations"), to allow nations to
disarm and safeguard the peace.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The term **New Commonwealth** has been used in the UK (especially in the 1960s
and 1970s) to refer to recently [decolonised](/wiki/Decolonization
"Decolonization") countries, predominantly non-[white](/wiki/White_race "White
race") and [developing](/wiki/Developing_country "Developing country"). It was
often used in debates about [immigration](/wiki/Immigration "Immigration")
from these countries.[27] Britain and the pre-1945 dominions became informally
known as the **Old Commonwealth** , or more pointedly as the **white
Commonwealth**.[28]

### Plan G and inviting Europe to
join[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Plan G and inviting Europe to join")]

At a time when Germany and France, together with Belgium, Italy, Luxembourg,
and the Netherlands, were planning for what later became the [European
Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"), and newly independent African
countries were joining the Commonwealth, new ideas were floated to prevent
Britain from becoming isolated in economic affairs. British trade with the
Commonwealth was four times larger than trade with Europe. The British
government under Prime Minister [Anthony Eden](/wiki/Anthony_Eden "Anthony
Eden") considered in 1956 and 1957 a "plan G" to create a European free trade
zone while also protecting the favoured status of the
Commonwealth.[29][30][31] Britain also considered inviting Scandinavian and
other European countries to join the Commonwealth so it would become a major
economic common market. At one point in October 1956 Eden and French Prime
Minister [Guy Mollet](/wiki/Guy_Mollet "Guy Mollet") discussed having France
join the Commonwealth.[32] Nothing came of any of the proposals.[33]

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Structure")]

### Head of the
Commonwealth[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Head of the Commonwealth")]

Main article: [Head of the Commonwealth](/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth "Head
of the Commonwealth")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Elizabeth_II%2C_Buckingham_Palace%2C_07_Mar_2006.jpeg/170px-
Elizabeth_II%2C_Buckingham_Palace%2C_07_Mar_2006.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Elizabeth_II,_Buckingham_Palace,_07_Mar_2006.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Elizabeth_II,_Buckingham_Palace,_07_Mar_2006.jpeg "Enlarge")

Queen [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II"), [Head of the
Commonwealth](/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth "Head of the Commonwealth")

Under the formula of the [London Declaration](/wiki/London_Declaration "London
Declaration"), Queen [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") is the
[Head of the Commonwealth](/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth "Head of the
Commonwealth"), a title that is by law a part of Elizabeth's royal titles in
each of the [Commonwealth realms](/wiki/Commonwealth_realm "Commonwealth
realm"),[34] the 16 members of the Commonwealth that recognise the Queen as
their [monarch](/wiki/Monarch "Monarch"). However, when the monarch dies, the
successor to the crown does not automatically become Head of the
Commonwealth.[35] The position is symbolic, representing the free association
of independent members,[34] the majority of which (31) are
[republics](/wiki/Republics_in_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations "Republics in the
Commonwealth of Nations"), and five have monarchs of different [royal
houses](/wiki/Royal_house "Royal house") ([Brunei](/wiki/Brunei "Brunei"),
[Lesotho](/wiki/Lesotho "Lesotho"), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia"),
[Swaziland](/wiki/Swaziland "Swaziland"), and [Tonga](/wiki/Tonga "Tonga")).

### Commonwealth Heads of Government
Meeting[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting")]

Main article: [Commonwealth Heads of Government
Meeting](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting "Commonwealth Heads of
Government Meeting")

The main decision-making forum of the organisation is the biennial
[Commonwealth Heads of Government
Meeting](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting "Commonwealth Heads of
Government Meeting") (CHOGM), where Commonwealth [heads of
government](/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government"), including (amongst
others) prime ministers and presidents, assemble for several days to discuss
matters of mutual interest. CHOGM is the successor to the Meetings of
Commonwealth Prime Ministers and, earlier, the [Imperial
Conferences](/wiki/Imperial_Conference "Imperial Conference") and Colonial
Conferences, dating back to 1887. There are also regular meetings of finance
ministers, law ministers, health ministers, etc. Members in arrears, as
special members before them, are not invited to send representatives to either
ministerial meetings or CHOGMs.[34]

The head of government hosting the CHOGM is called the _[Commonwealth
Chairperson-in-Office](/wiki/Commonwealth_Chairperson-in-Office "Commonwealth
Chairperson-in-Office")_ and retains the position until the following
CHOGM.[36] After [the most recent
CHOGM](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2018 "Commonwealth Heads
of Government Meeting 2018"), in [London, UK](/wiki/London "London"), from 18
to 20 April 2018 [the UK's prime
minister](/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_the_United_Kingdom "Prime Minister of the
United Kingdom"), [Theresa May](/wiki/Theresa_May "Theresa May"), became the
Chairperson-in-Office and will continue to hold the title until the next
CHOGM, scheduled to take place in [Rwanda in
2020](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2020 "Commonwealth Heads
of Government Meeting 2020").

### Commonwealth
Secretariat[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Commonwealth Secretariat")]

Main article: [Commonwealth Secretariat](/wiki/Commonwealth_Secretariat
"Commonwealth Secretariat")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/Marlborough_House.jpg/220px-
Marlborough_House.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marlborough_House.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Marlborough_House.jpg "Enlarge")

[Marlborough House](/wiki/Marlborough_House "Marlborough House"), London, the
headquarters of the [Commonwealth Secretariat](/wiki/Commonwealth_Secretariat
"Commonwealth Secretariat"), the Commonwealth's principal intergovernmental
institution

The [Commonwealth Secretariat](/wiki/Commonwealth_Secretariat "Commonwealth
Secretariat"), established in 1965, is the main intergovernmental agency of
the Commonwealth, facilitating consultation and co-operation among member
governments and countries. It is responsible to member governments
collectively. The Commonwealth of Nations is represented in the [United
Nations General Assembly](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly "United
Nations General Assembly") by the secretariat as an
[observer](/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_observers "United Nations
General Assembly observers"). The secretariat organises Commonwealth summits,
meetings of ministers, consultative meetings and technical discussions; it
assists policy development and provides policy advice, and facilitates
multilateral communication among the member governments. It also provides
technical assistance to help governments in the social and economic
development of their countries and in support of the Commonwealth's
fundamental political values.[37]

The secretariat is headed by the [Commonwealth Secretary-
General](/wiki/Commonwealth_Secretary-General "Commonwealth Secretary-
General") who is elected by [Commonwealth heads of
government](/wiki/List_of_Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government "List of
Commonwealth Heads of Government") for no more than two four-year terms. The
secretary-general and two deputy secretaries-general direct the divisions of
the Secretariat. The present secretary-general is [Patricia Scotland, Baroness
Scotland of Asthal](/wiki/Patricia_Scotland,_Baroness_Scotland_of_Asthal
"Patricia Scotland, Baroness Scotland of Asthal"), from
[Dominica](/wiki/Dominica "Dominica"), who took office on 1 April 2016,
succeeding [Kamalesh Sharma](/wiki/Kamalesh_Sharma "Kamalesh Sharma") of
[India](/wiki/India "India") (2008–2016). The first secretary-general was
[Arnold Smith](/wiki/Arnold_Smith "Arnold Smith") of [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada") (1965–75), followed by Sir [Shridath Ramphal](/wiki/Shridath_Ramphal
"Shridath Ramphal") of [Guyana](/wiki/Guyana "Guyana") (1975–90), Chief [Emeka
Anyaoku](/wiki/Emeka_Anyaoku "Emeka Anyaoku") of [Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria
"Nigeria") (1990–99), and [Don McKinnon](/wiki/Don_McKinnon "Don McKinnon") of
[New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand") (2000–2008).[37]

### Commonwealth citizenship and high
commissioners[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Commonwealth citizenship and high commissioners")]

Main article: [Commonwealth citizen](/wiki/Commonwealth_citizen "Commonwealth
citizen")

In recognition of their shared heritage and culture, Commonwealth countries
are not considered to be "foreign" to each other,[38][39][40] although the
technical extent of this concept varies in different countries. For example,
in Australia, for the purpose of considering certain constitutional and legal
provisions no distinction is made between Commonwealth and foreign countries:
in the [High Court](/wiki/High_Court_of_Australia "High Court of Australia")
case of _[Sue v Hill](/wiki/Sue_v_Hill "Sue v Hill")_ , other Commonwealth
countries were held to be foreign powers; similarly, in _Nolan v Minister for
Immigration and Ethnic Affairs_ , the nationals of other Commonwealth realms
were held to be 'aliens'. Nevertheless, the closer association amongst
Commonwealth countries is reflected at least in the diplomatic protocols of
the Commonwealth countries. For example, when engaging bilaterally with one
another, Commonwealth governments exchange [high
commissioners](/wiki/High_commissioner_\(Commonwealth\) "High commissioner
\(Commonwealth\)") instead of [ambassadors](/wiki/Ambassador "Ambassador").
Between two Commonwealth realms, they represent the [head of
government](/wiki/Head_of_government "Head of government") rather than the
[head of state](/wiki/Head_of_state "Head of state").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In addition, some members treat resident citizens of other Commonwealth
countries preferentially to citizens of non-Commonwealth countries. Britain
and several others, mostly in the [Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean "Caribbean"),
grant [the right to vote](/wiki/Right_of_foreigners_to_vote "Right of
foreigners to vote") to Commonwealth citizens who reside in those countries.
In non-Commonwealth countries in which their own country is not represented,
Commonwealth citizens may seek [consular assistance](/wiki/Consular_assistance
"Consular assistance") at the British embassy.[41] Other alternatives can also
occur such as an emergency consular services agreement between Canada and
Australia that began in 1986.[42]

##
Membership[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Membership")]

###
Criteria[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Criteria")]

Main article: [Commonwealth of Nations membership
criteria](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations_membership_criteria "Commonwealth of
Nations membership criteria")

The criteria for membership of the Commonwealth of Nations have developed over
time from a series of separate documents. The [Statute of Westminster
1931](/wiki/Statute_of_Westminster_1931 "Statute of Westminster 1931"), as a
fundamental founding document of the organisation, laid out that membership
required dominionhood. The 1949 [London Declaration](/wiki/London_Declaration
"London Declaration") ended this, allowing republican and indigenous monarchic
members on the condition that they recognised the British monarch as the
"[Head of the Commonwealth](/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth "Head of the
Commonwealth")".[43] In the wake of the wave of
[decolonisation](/wiki/Decolonisation "Decolonisation") in the 1960s, these
constitutional principles were augmented by political, economic, and social
principles. The first of these was set out in 1961, when it was decided that
respect for [racial equality](/wiki/Racial_equality "Racial equality") would
be a requirement for membership, leading directly to the withdrawal of South
Africa's re-application (which they were required to make under the formula of
the London Declaration upon becoming a republic). The 14 points of the 1971
[Singapore Declaration](/wiki/Singapore_Declaration "Singapore Declaration")
dedicated all members to the principles of [world peace](/wiki/World_peace
"World peace"), [liberty](/wiki/Liberty "Liberty"), [human
rights](/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights"), [equality](/wiki/Egalitarianism
"Egalitarianism"), and [free trade](/wiki/Free_trade "Free trade").[44]

These criteria were unenforceable for two decades,[45] until, in 1991, the
[Harare Declaration](/wiki/Harare_Declaration "Harare Declaration") was
issued, dedicating the leaders to applying the Singapore principles to the
completion of decolonisation, the end of the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold
War"), and the end of [apartheid](/wiki/Apartheid "Apartheid") in South
Africa.[46] The mechanisms by which these principles would be applied were
created, and the manner clarified, by the 1995 [Millbrook Commonwealth Action
Programme](/wiki/Millbrook_Commonwealth_Action_Programme "Millbrook
Commonwealth Action Programme"), which created the [Commonwealth Ministerial
Action Group](/wiki/Commonwealth_Ministerial_Action_Group "Commonwealth
Ministerial Action Group") (CMAG), which has the power to rule on whether
members meet the requirements for membership under the Harare Declaration.[47]
Also in 1995, an Inter-Governmental Group was created to finalise and codify
the full requirements for membership. Upon reporting in 1997, as adopted under
the [Edinburgh Declaration](/wiki/Edinburgh_Declaration "Edinburgh
Declaration"), the Inter-Governmental Group ruled that any future members
would have to have a direct constitutional link with an existing member.[48]

In addition to this new rule, the former rules were consolidated into a single
document. These requirements are that members must accept and comply with the
[Harare principles](/wiki/Harare_Declaration "Harare Declaration"), be fully
[sovereign](/wiki/Sovereignty "Sovereignty") states, recognise the monarch of
the [Commonwealth realms](/wiki/Commonwealth_realms "Commonwealth realms") as
the [Head of the Commonwealth](/wiki/Head_of_the_Commonwealth "Head of the
Commonwealth"), accept the [English language](/wiki/English_language "English
language") as the means of Commonwealth communication, and respect the wishes
of the general population with regard to Commonwealth membership.[48] These
requirements had undergone review, and a report on potential amendments was
presented by the [Committee on Commonwealth
Membership](/wiki/Committee_on_Commonwealth_Membership "Committee on
Commonwealth Membership") at the [2007 Commonwealth Heads of Government
Meeting](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2007 "Commonwealth
Heads of Government Meeting 2007").[49] New members were not admitted at this
meeting, though applications for admission were considered at the [2009
CHOGM](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2009 "Commonwealth Heads
of Government Meeting 2009").[50]

New members must "as a general rule" have a direct constitutional link to an
existing member. In most cases, this is due to being a former colony of the
United Kingdom, but some have links to other countries, either exclusively or
more directly (e.g. [Samoa](/wiki/Samoa "Samoa") to New Zealand, [Papua New
Guinea](/wiki/Papua_New_Guinea "Papua New Guinea") to Australia, and
[Namibia](/wiki/Namibia "Namibia") to South Africa). The first member to be
admitted without having any constitutional link to the British Empire or a
Commonwealth member was [Mozambique](/wiki/Mozambique "Mozambique"), a former
[Portuguese colony](/wiki/Portuguese_Empire "Portuguese Empire"), in 1995
following its first democratic elections and South Africa's re-admission in
1994. Mozambique's controversial entry led to the [Edinburgh
Declaration](/wiki/Edinburgh_Declaration "Edinburgh Declaration") and the
current membership guidelines.[51] In 2009, [Rwanda](/wiki/Rwanda "Rwanda")
became the second Commonwealth member admitted not to have any such
constitutional links. It was a Belgian [trust
territory](/wiki/United_Nations_Trust_Territories "United Nations Trust
Territories") that had been a German colony until [World War
I](/wiki/World_War_I "World War I").[52] Consideration for its admission was
considered an "exceptional circumstance" by the [Commonwealth
Secretariat](/wiki/Commonwealth_Secretariat "Commonwealth Secretariat").[53]

###
Members[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Members")]

Main article: [Member states of the Commonwealth of
Nations](/wiki/Member_states_of_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations "Member states of
the Commonwealth of Nations")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Parliament_Square_11-3-09_%288543941393%29.jpg/220px-
Parliament_Square_11-3-09_%288543941393%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Parliament_Square_11-3-09_\(8543941393\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Parliament_Square_11-3-09_\(8543941393\).jpg "Enlarge")

Flags of the members of the Commonwealth in [Parliament
Square](/wiki/Parliament_Square "Parliament Square"), London

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Commonwealth_flag_Ottawa.jpg/170px-
Commonwealth_flag_Ottawa.jpg)](/wiki/File:Commonwealth_flag_Ottawa.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Commonwealth_flag_Ottawa.jpg "Enlarge")

The Commonwealth flag flying at the [Parliament of
Canada](/wiki/Parliament_of_Canada "Parliament of Canada") in
[Ottawa](/wiki/Ottawa "Ottawa")

The Commonwealth comprises 53 countries, across all continents. The members
have a combined population of 2.3 billion people, almost a third of the world
population, of which 1.26 billion live in [India](/wiki/India "India") and 94%
live in Asia and Africa combined.[54] After [India](/wiki/India "India"), the
next-largest Commonwealth countries by population are
[Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") (180 million), [Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria
"Nigeria") (170 million), [Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh") (156
million), the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") (65
million), [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") (55 million)
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") (36 million), [Ghana](/wiki/Ghana "Ghana") (27
million) and [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") (24 million).
[Tuvalu](/wiki/Tuvalu "Tuvalu") is the smallest member, with about 10,000
people.[55]

The land area of the Commonwealth nations is about 31,500,000 km2 (12,200,000
sq mi), or about 21% of the total world land area. The three largest
Commonwealth nations by area are [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") at 9,984,670
km2 (3,855,100 sq mi), [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") at 7,617,930
km2 (2,941,300 sq mi), and [India](/wiki/India "India") at 3,287,263 km2
(1,269,219 sq mi).[56] In 2016, the Commonwealth members had a combined [gross
domestic product](/wiki/Gross_domestic_product "Gross domestic product") of
over $9 trillion, 78% of which is accounted for by the four largest economies:
[United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") ($2.629 trillion),
[India](/wiki/India "India") ($2.256 trillion), [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada") ($1.529 trillion), and [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia")
($1.258 trillion).[57]

The status of "Member in Arrears" is used to denote those that are in arrears
in paying subscription dues. The status was originally known as "[special
membership](/wiki/Special_membership_of_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations "Special
membership of the Commonwealth of Nations")", but was renamed on the
[Committee on Commonwealth
Membership](/wiki/Committee_on_Commonwealth_Membership "Committee on
Commonwealth Membership")'s recommendation.[58] There are currently no Members
in Arrears. The most recent Member in Arrears, [Nauru](/wiki/Nauru "Nauru"),
returned to full membership in June 2011.[59] Nauru has alternated between
special and full membership since joining the Commonwealth, depending on its
financial situation.[60]

###
Applicants[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Applicants")]

See also: [Commonwealth of Nations membership criteria § Prospective
members](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Nations_membership_criteria#Prospective_members
"Commonwealth of Nations membership criteria")

In 1997 the Commonwealth Heads of Government agreed that, to become a member
of the Commonwealth, an applicant country should, as a rule, have had a
constitutional association with an existing Commonwealth member; that it
should comply with Commonwealth values, principles and priorities as set out
in the [Harare Declaration](/wiki/Harare_Declaration "Harare Declaration");
and that it should accept Commonwealth norms and conventions.[61]

[South Sudanese](/wiki/South_Sudan "South Sudan") politicians have expressed
interest in joining the Commonwealth.[62] A senior Commonwealth source stated
in 2006 that "many people have assumed an interest from [Israel](/wiki/Israel
"Israel"), but there has been no formal approach".[63] The [State of
Palestine](/wiki/State_of_Palestine "State of Palestine") is also a potential
candidate for membership.[63]

President [Yahya Jammeh](/wiki/Yahya_Jammeh "Yahya Jammeh") unilaterally
withdrew [The Gambia](/wiki/The_Gambia "The Gambia") from the Commonwealth in
October 2013.[64] However, [newly
elected](/wiki/Gambian_presidential_election,_2016 "Gambian presidential
election, 2016") president [Adama Barrow](/wiki/Adama_Barrow "Adama Barrow")
returned the country to the organisation in February 2018.[65]

Other eligible applicants could be any of the remaining inhabited [British
overseas territories](/wiki/British_overseas_territories "British overseas
territories"), [Crown dependencies](/wiki/Crown_dependencies "Crown
dependencies"), [Australian external
territories](/wiki/States_and_territories_of_Australia#External "States and
territories of Australia") and the [Associated States of New
Zealand](/wiki/Associated_States_of_New_Zealand "Associated States of New
Zealand") if they become fully independent.[66] Many such jurisdictions are
already directly represented within the Commonwealth, particularly through the
[Commonwealth Family](/wiki/Commonwealth_Family "Commonwealth Family").[67]
There are also former British possessions that have not become independent,
for example, Hong Kong, which still participates in some of the institutions
within the Commonwealth Family. All three [Crown
dependencies](/wiki/Crown_dependencies "Crown dependencies") regard the
existing situation as unsatisfactory and have lobbied for change. The [States
of Jersey](/wiki/States_of_Jersey "States of Jersey") have called on the UK
Foreign Secretary to request that the Commonwealth Heads of Government
"consider granting associate membership to Jersey and the other Crown
Dependencies as well as any other territories at a similarly advanced stage of
autonomy". Jersey has proposed that it be accorded "self-representation in all
Commonwealth meetings; full participation in debates and procedures, with a
right to speak where relevant and the opportunity to enter into discussions
with those who are full members; and no right to vote in the Ministerial or
Heads of Government meetings, which is reserved for full members".[68] The
[States of Guernsey](/wiki/States_of_Guernsey "States of Guernsey") and the
[Government of the Isle of Man](/wiki/Government_of_the_Isle_of_Man
"Government of the Isle of Man") have made calls of a similar nature for a
more integrated relationship with the Commonwealth,[69] including more direct
representation and enhanced participation in Commonwealth organisations and
meetings, including Commonwealth Heads of Government Meetings.[70] The [Chief
Minister of the Isle of Man](/wiki/Chief_Minister_of_the_Isle_of_Man "Chief
Minister of the Isle of Man") has said: "A closer connection with the
Commonwealth itself would be a welcome further development of the Island's
international relationships".[71]

At the time of the [Suez Crisis](/wiki/Suez_Crisis "Suez Crisis") in 1956, in
the face of colonial unrest and international tensions, French Premier [Guy
Mollet](/wiki/Guy_Mollet "Guy Mollet") proposed to British Prime Minister
[Anthony Eden](/wiki/Anthony_Eden "Anthony Eden") that their two countries be
[joined in a "union"](/wiki/Franco-British_Union#Suez_Crisis_\(1956\) "Franco-
British Union"). When that proposal was turned down, Mollet suggested that
France join the Commonwealth, possibly with "a common citizenship arrangement
[on the Irish basis](/wiki/British_nationality_law_and_the_Republic_of_Ireland
"British nationality law and the Republic of Ireland")." Talks regarding a
form of union faded away with the end of the Suez crisis.[72]

###
Suspension[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=18
"Edit section: Suspension")]

Main article: [Suspension from the Commonwealth of
Nations](/wiki/Suspension_from_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations "Suspension from
the Commonwealth of Nations")

In recent years, the Commonwealth has suspended several members "from the
Councils of the Commonwealth" for "serious or persistent violations" of the
[Harare Declaration](/wiki/Harare_Declaration "Harare Declaration"),
particularly in abrogating their responsibility to have democratic
government.[73] This is done by the [Commonwealth Ministerial Action
Group](/wiki/Commonwealth_Ministerial_Action_Group "Commonwealth Ministerial
Action Group") (CMAG), which meets regularly to address potential breaches of
the Harare Declaration. Suspended members are not represented at meetings of
Commonwealth leaders and ministers, although they remain members of the
organisation. Currently, there are no suspended members.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[Nigeria](/wiki/Nigeria "Nigeria") was suspended between 11 November 1995 and
29 May 1999,[74] following its execution of [Ken Saro-Wiwa](/wiki/Ken_Saro-
Wiwa "Ken Saro-Wiwa") on the eve of the [1995
CHOGM](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_1995 "Commonwealth Heads
of Government Meeting 1995").[75] [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") was
the second country to be suspended, on 18 October 1999, following the
[military coup](/wiki/1999_Pakistani_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "1999 Pakistani coup
d'état") by [Pervez Musharraf](/wiki/Pervez_Musharraf "Pervez Musharraf").[76]
The Commonwealth's longest suspension came to an end on 22 May 2004, when
Pakistan's suspension was lifted following the restoration of [the country's
constitution](/wiki/Constitution_of_Pakistan "Constitution of Pakistan").[77]
Pakistan was suspended for a second time, far more briefly, for six months
from 22 November 2007, when Musharraf [called a state of
emergency](/wiki/2007_Pakistani_state_of_emergency "2007 Pakistani state of
emergency").[78] [Zimbabwe](/wiki/Zimbabwe "Zimbabwe") was suspended in 2002
over concerns regarding the electoral and land reform policies of [Robert
Mugabe](/wiki/Robert_Mugabe "Robert Mugabe")'s [ZANU-
PF](/wiki/Zimbabwe_African_National_Union_%E2%80%93_Patriotic_Front "Zimbabwe
African National Union – Patriotic Front") government,[79] before it withdrew
from the organisation in 2003.[80] On 15 May 2018, Zimbabwe applied to rejoin
the Commonwealth.[81]

The declaration of a Republic in [Fiji](/wiki/Fiji "Fiji") in 1987, after
[military coups](/wiki/1987_Fijian_coups_d%27%C3%A9tat "1987 Fijian coups
d'état") designed to deny [Indo-Fijians](/wiki/Indians_in_Fiji "Indians in
Fiji") political power, was not accompanied by an application to remain.
Commonwealth membership was held to have lapsed until 1997, after
discriminatory provisions in the republican constitution were repealed and
reapplication for membership made.[82][83] Fiji has since been suspended
twice, with the first imposed from 6 June 2000[84] to 20 December 2001 after
[another coup](/wiki/2000_Fijian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "2000 Fijian coup
d'état").[79] Fiji was suspended yet again in December 2006, following [the
most recent coup](/wiki/2006_Fijian_coup_d%27%C3%A9tat "2006 Fijian coup
d'état"). At first, the suspension applied only to membership on the Councils
of the Commonwealth.[82][85] After failing to meet a Commonwealth deadline for
setting a date for national elections by 2010, Fiji was "fully suspended" on 1
September 2009.[82][85] The Secretary-General of the Commonwealth, [Kamalesh
Sharma](/wiki/Kamalesh_Sharma "Kamalesh Sharma"), confirmed that full
suspension meant that Fiji would be excluded from Commonwealth meetings,
[sporting events](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games") and the
technical assistance programme (with an exception for assistance in re-
establishing democracy). Sharma stated that Fiji would remain a member of the
Commonwealth during its suspension, but would be excluded from emblematic
representation by the secretariat.[82] On 19 March 2014 Fiji's full suspension
was amended to a suspension from councils of the Commonwealth by the
Commonwealth Ministerial Action Group, permitting Fiji to join a number of
Commonwealth activities, including the Commonwealth Games.[86] Fiji's
suspension was lifted in September 2014.[87] The Commonwealth Ministerial
Action Group fully reinstated Fiji as a member following
[elections](/wiki/Fijian_general_election,_2014 "Fijian general election,
2014") in September 2014.[88]

Most recently, during 2013 and 2014, international pressure mounted to suspend
[Sri Lanka](/wiki/Sri_Lanka "Sri Lanka") from the Commonwealth, citing grave
human rights violations by the government of President [Mahinda
Rajapaksa](/wiki/Mahinda_Rajapaksa "Mahinda Rajapaksa"). There were also calls
to change the [Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting
2013](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2013 "Commonwealth Heads
of Government Meeting 2013") from Sri Lanka to another member country.
Canadian prime minister [Stephen Harper](/wiki/Stephen_Harper "Stephen
Harper") threatened to boycott the event, but was instead represented at the
meeting by [Deepak Obhrai](/wiki/Deepak_Obhrai "Deepak Obhrai"). UK Prime
Minister [David Cameron](/wiki/David_Cameron "David Cameron") also chose to
attend.[89][90] These concerns were rendered moot by [the
election](/wiki/Sri_Lankan_presidential_election,_2015 "Sri Lankan
presidential election, 2015") of opposition leader [Maithripala
Sirisena](/wiki/Maithripala_Sirisena "Maithripala Sirisena") as President in
2015.

###
Termination[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=19
"Edit section: Termination")]

As membership is purely voluntary, member governments can choose at any time
to leave the Commonwealth. [Pakistan](/wiki/Pakistan "Pakistan") left on 30
January 1972 in protest at the Commonwealth's recognition of breakaway
[Bangladesh](/wiki/Bangladesh "Bangladesh"), but rejoined on 2 August 1989.
Zimbabwe's membership was suspended in 2002 on the grounds of alleged human
rights violations and deliberate misgovernment, and Zimbabwe's government
terminated its membership in 2003.[91] [The Gambia](/wiki/The_Gambia "The
Gambia") left the Commonwealth on 3 October 2013,[64] and rejoined on 8
February 2018.[65] The Maldives withdrew from the Commonwealth on 13 October
2016.[92] The [Maldivian Ministry of Foreign
Affairs](/wiki/Minister_of_Foreign_Affairs_\(Maldives\) "Minister of Foreign
Affairs \(Maldives\)") stated that "the Commonwealth has not recognised [...]
the progress and achievements that the Maldives accomplished in cultivating a
culture of democracy in the country and in building and strengthening
democratic institutions".[93] The Ministry also cited the Commonwealth's
"punitive actions against the Maldives since 2012" after the [allegedly forced
resignation](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-16945764) of Maldivian
President [Mohamed Nasheed](/wiki/Mohamed_Nasheed "Mohamed Nasheed") among the
reasons for withdrawal.[93] The Ministry characterized the decision to
withdraw as "difficult, but inevitable".[93]

Although heads of government have the power to suspend member states from
active participation, the Commonwealth has no provision for the expulsion of
members. Until 2007, [Commonwealth realms](/wiki/Commonwealth_realm
"Commonwealth realm") that became [republics](/wiki/Republic "Republic")
automatically ceased to be members, until (like India in 1950) they obtained
the permission of other members to remain in the organisation. This policy has
been changed, so if any current Commonwealth realms were to become republics,
they would not have to go through this process.[94]

[Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland") had withdrawn its
participation in the Commonwealth in the 1930s, attending its last
Commonwealth governmental heads' meeting in 1932. However it continued to be
regarded by the Commonwealth as a Commonwealth member until it declared itself
a republic, on 18 April 1949. It is the only country whose membership
terminated without any declaration withdrawing from the organisation. Instead,
it was (with its own tacit support) excluded from the organisation under the
rules then applicable.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

[South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") was barred from continuing
as a member after it became a republic in 1961, due to hostility from many
members, particularly those in Africa and Asia as well as Canada, to its
policy of racial [apartheid](/wiki/Apartheid "Apartheid"). The South African
government withdrew its application to remain in the organisation as a
republic when it became clear at the [1961 Commonwealth Prime Ministers'
Conference](/wiki/1961_Commonwealth_Prime_Ministers%27_Conference "1961
Commonwealth Prime Ministers' Conference") that any such application would be
rejected. South Africa was re-admitted to the Commonwealth in 1994, following
its [first multiracial elections](/wiki/South_African_general_election,_1994
"South African general election, 1994") that year.[95]

The [transfer of sovereignty over Hong
Kong](/wiki/Transfer_of_sovereignty_over_Hong_Kong "Transfer of sovereignty
over Hong Kong") in 1997 ended the colony's ties to the Commonwealth through
the United Kingdom. The government of Hong Kong, as a [special administrative
region](/wiki/Special_Administrative_Region_of_the_People%27s_Republic_of_China
"Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China") of China,
did not pursue membership. Hong Kong has nevertheless continued to participate
in some of the organisations of the Commonwealth family, such as the
[Commonwealth Lawyers Association](/wiki/Commonwealth_Lawyers_Association
"Commonwealth Lawyers Association") (hosted the Commonwealth Lawyers
Conference in 1983 and 2009), the [Commonwealth Parliamentary
Association](/wiki/Commonwealth_Parliamentary_Association "Commonwealth
Parliamentary Association") (and the Westminster Seminar on Parliamentary
Practice and Procedures), the [Association of Commonwealth
Universities](/wiki/Association_of_Commonwealth_Universities "Association of
Commonwealth Universities") and the Commonwealth Association of Legislative
Counsel.[96][97]

##
Politics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=20
"Edit section: Politics")]

### Objectives and
activities[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=21
"Edit section: Objectives and activities")]

The Commonwealth's objectives were first outlined in the 1971 [Singapore
Declaration](/wiki/Singapore_Declaration "Singapore Declaration"), which
committed the Commonwealth to the institution of [world
peace](/wiki/World_peace "World peace"); promotion of [representative
democracy](/wiki/Representative_democracy "Representative democracy") and
[individual liberty](/wiki/Individual_liberty "Individual liberty"); the
pursuit of equality and opposition to racism; the fight against poverty,
ignorance, and disease; and [free trade](/wiki/Free_trade "Free trade").[98]
To these were added opposition to discrimination on the basis of gender by the
[Lusaka Declaration](/wiki/Lusaka_Declaration "Lusaka Declaration") of
1979,[44] and [environmental
sustainability](/wiki/Environmental_sustainability "Environmental
sustainability") by the [Langkawi Declaration](/wiki/Langkawi_Declaration
"Langkawi Declaration") of 1989.[99] These objectives were reinforced by the
[Harare Declaration](/wiki/Harare_Declaration "Harare Declaration") in
1991.[100]

The Commonwealth's current highest-priority aims are on the promotion of
democracy and development, as outlined in the 2003 [Aso Rock
Declaration](/wiki/Aso_Rock "Aso Rock"),[101] which built on those in
Singapore and Harare and clarified their terms of reference, stating, "We are
committed to democracy, good governance, human rights, gender equality, and a
more equitable sharing of the benefits of globalisation."[102] The
Commonwealth website lists its areas of work as: democracy, economics,
education, gender, governance, human rights, law, small states, sport,
sustainability, and youth.[103]

Through a separate voluntary fund, Commonwealth governments support the
[Commonwealth Youth Programme](/wiki/Commonwealth_Youth_Programme
"Commonwealth Youth Programme"), a division of the Secretariat with offices in
[Gulu](/wiki/Gulu "Gulu") (Uganda), [Lusaka](/wiki/Lusaka "Lusaka") (Zambia),
[Chandigarh](/wiki/Chandigarh "Chandigarh") (India),
[Georgetown](/wiki/Georgetown,_Guyana "Georgetown, Guyana") (Guyana) and
[Honiara](/wiki/Honiara "Honiara") (Solomon Islands).[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Competence[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=22
"Edit section: Competence")]

In recent years, the Commonwealth has been accused of not being vocal enough
on its core values. Allegations of a leaked memo from the Secretary General
instructing staff not to speak out on human rights were published in October
2010.[104]

The [Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting
2011](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_2011 "Commonwealth Heads
of Government Meeting 2011") considered a report by a [Commonwealth Eminent
Persons Group](/wiki/Commonwealth_Eminent_Persons_Group "Commonwealth Eminent
Persons Group") (EPG) panel which asserted that the organisation had lost its
relevance and was decaying due to the lack of a mechanism to censure member
countries when they violated human rights or democratic norms.[105] The panel
made 106 "urgent" recommendations including the adoption of a Charter of the
Commonwealth, the creation of a new commissioner on the rule of law, democracy
and human rights to track persistent human rights abuses and allegations of
political repression by Commonwealth member states, recommendations for the
repeal of [laws against](/wiki/LGBT_rights_by_country_or_territory "LGBT
rights by country or territory") [homosexuality](/wiki/Homosexuality
"Homosexuality") in 41 Commonwealth states and a ban on [forced
marriage](/wiki/Forced_marriage "Forced marriage").[106][107] The failure to
release the report, or accept its recommendations for reforms in the area of
human rights, democracy and the rule of law, was decried as a "disgrace" by
former British Foreign Secretary Sir [Malcolm Rifkind](/wiki/Malcolm_Rifkind
"Malcolm Rifkind"), a member of the EPG, who told a press conference: "The
Commonwealth faces a very significant problem. It's not a problem of hostility
or antagonism, it's more of a problem of indifference. Its purpose is being
questioned, its relevance is being questioned and part of that is because its
commitment to enforce the values for which it stands is becoming ambiguous in
the eyes of many member states. The Commonwealth is not a private club of the
governments or the secretariat. It belongs to the people of the
Commonwealth."[107]

In the end, two-thirds of the EPG's 106 urgently recommended reforms were
referred to study groups, an act described by one EPG member as having them
"kicked into the long grass". There was no agreement to create the recommended
position of human rights commissioner, instead a ministerial management group
was empowered with enforcement: the group includes alleged human rights
offenders. It was agreed to develop a charter of values for the Commonwealth
without any decision on how compliance with its principles would be
enforced.[105]

The result of the effort was that a new [Charter of the
Commonwealth](/wiki/Charter_of_the_Commonwealth "Charter of the Commonwealth")
was signed by Queen Elizabeth on 11 March 2013 at Marlborough House, which
opposes "all forms of discrimination, whether rooted in gender, race, colour,
creed, political belief or other grounds".[108][109]

### Proposed free movement
policy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=23
"Edit section: Proposed free movement policy")]

In March 2015, the [Commonwealth Freedom of Movement
Organisation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Freedom_of_Movement_Organisation
"Commonwealth Freedom of Movement Organisation") proposed that the national
governments of the [United Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"),
[Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), [New Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New
Zealand") and [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") should advocate for freedom of
movement between citizens of their countries, similar to the current
arrangement existing between Australia and New Zealand through the [Trans-
Tasman Travel Arrangement](/wiki/Trans-Tasman_Travel_Arrangement "Trans-Tasman
Travel Arrangement").[110] In May 2016, Australian High Commissioner to the
United Kingdom [Alexander Downer](/wiki/Alexander_Downer "Alexander Downer")
expressed support for "freer movement" between Australia and the United
Kingdom, stating: "Over time we would like to continue to talk to the British
government about arrangements we could make to liberalise movement between
Australia and the UK, if not have completely free movement...".[111]
