###
Postwar[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=26
"Edit section: Postwar")]

During the Second World War, the Commonwealth played a major role in helping
British finances. Foreign exchange reserves were pooled in London, to be used
to fight the war. In effect Britain borrowed £2.3 billion, of which £1.3
billion was from India. The debt was held in the form of British government
securities and became known as "sterling balances." By 1950, India, Pakistan
and Ceylon had spent much of their sterling, while other countries accumulated
more. The sterling area that included all of the Commonwealth except for
Canada, together with some smaller countries especially in the Persian Gulf.
They held their foreign-exchange in sterling, protecting that currency from
runs, and facilitating trade and investment inside the Commonwealth. It was a
formal relationship with fixed exchange rates, and periodic meetings at
Commonwealth summits to coordinate trade policy, and domestic economic
policies. Britain ran a trade surplus, and the other countries were mostly
producers of raw materials sold to Britain. However the British economy was
sluggish, compared to Western Europe, by the 1960s, and the commercial
rationale was gradually less attractive to the Commonwealth. Access to the
growing London capital market, however, remained an important advantage to the
newly independent nations. As Britain moved increasingly close to Europe,
however, the long-term ties began to be in doubt.[117]

#### UK joins the European Economic
Community[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=27
"Edit section: UK joins the European Economic Community")]

Britain had focused on the Commonwealth after the war, and largely ignored
links with Europe. By the 1960s with a sluggish economy Britain tried
repeatedly to join the [European Economic
Community](/wiki/European_Economic_Community "European Economic Community"),
but this was repeatedly vetoed by [Charles de Gaulle](/wiki/Charles_de_Gaulle
"Charles de Gaulle").[118] After his death, [entry was finally achieved in
1972.](/wiki/European_Communities_Act_1972_\(UK\) "European Communities Act
1972 \(UK\)") Queen Elizabeth was one of the few remaining links between the
UK and the Commonwealth. She tried to reassure the other countries that the
Commonwealth family was joining forces with the Europeans, and that the new
links would not replace the old Commonwealth ties based on historical
attachments, which were too sacred to break. Historian [Ben
Pimlott](/wiki/Ben_Pimlott "Ben Pimlott") argues that she was mistaken, for
joining Europe, "constituted the most decisive step yet in the progress of
severance of familial ties between Britain and its former Empire....It reduced
the remaining links to sentimental and cultural ones, and legal
niceties."[119]

The newly independent countries of Africa and Asia concentrated on their own
internal political and economic development, and sometimes with their role in
the [Cold War](/wiki/Cold_War "Cold War"). The United States, international
agencies, and the Soviet Union became important players, and the British role
receded. Indeed, the British considered them burdensome and were themselves
alienated from traditional imperialism. The former colonies would rather have
a prosperous Britain linked to a prosperous Europe, rather than a declining
loner.[120] The dominions saw that their historic ties with Britain were
rapidly fraying. The Canadian economy was increasingly integrated with the
United States, and had less and less to do with Britain or other Commonwealth
nations. Internal Canadian disputes revolved around the growing American
cultural economic presence, and the strong force of Québec nationalism and
even independence. In 1964 the [Maple Leaf flag](/wiki/Flag_of_Canada "Flag of
Canada") replaced the old Union Jack to the sorrow of many Anglophiles—it was
"the last gasp of empire."[121] Australia and New Zealand were in deep shock
but kept a low profile not wanting to alienate London.[122][123] Nevertheless,
the implications of British entry into Europe:

    seemed shattering to most Australians, particularly to older people and conservatives. In fact the United Kingdom, as Australia's chief trading partner, was being very rapidly replaced just at this time by the United States and an economically resurgent Japan, but most people were scarcely aware of this.... It was feared that British entry into the Common Market was bound to mean abolition, or at least scaling down, of preferential tariff arrangements for Australians goods.[124]

###
Trade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=28
"Edit section: Trade")]

Further information: [Commonwealth free trade](/wiki/Commonwealth_free_trade
"Commonwealth free trade")

Although the Commonwealth does not have a multilateral trade agreement,
research by the [Royal Commonwealth Society](/wiki/Royal_Commonwealth_Society
"Royal Commonwealth Society") has shown that [trade](/wiki/Trade "Trade") with
another Commonwealth member is up to 50% more than with a non-member on
average, with smaller and less wealthy states having a higher propensity to
trade within the Commonwealth.[125] At the 2005 Summit in Malta, the heads of
government endorsed pursuing free trade among Commonwealth members on a
bilateral basis.[126]

There have been various proposals for a Commonwealth free trade zone,[127]
however none have so far come to pass. Following its vote in June 2016 to
leave the EU, some politicians in the United Kingdom have suggested the idea
as an alternative to its [membership](/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union
"Member state of the European Union") in the [European
Union](/wiki/European_Union "European Union"),[128][129] however it is far
from clear that this would either offer sufficient economic benefit to replace
the impact of leaving the EU or be acceptable to other member states[130]
Although the EU is already in the process of negotiating free trade agreements
with many Commonwealth countries such as India and Canada, it took the EU
almost ten years to come to an agreement with Canada,[131][132] due to the
challenge associated with achieving the necessary EU-wide approvals.

## Commonwealth
Family[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=29
"Edit section: Commonwealth Family")]

Main article: [Commonwealth Family](/wiki/Commonwealth_Family "Commonwealth
Family")

Commonwealth countries share many links outside government, with over a
hundred Commonwealth-wide non-governmental organisations, notably for sport,
culture, education, law and charity. The [Association of Commonwealth
Universities](/wiki/Association_of_Commonwealth_Universities "Association of
Commonwealth Universities") is an important vehicle for academic links,
particularly through scholarships, principally the [Commonwealth
Scholarship](/wiki/Commonwealth_Scholarship "Commonwealth Scholarship"), for
students to study in [universities](/wiki/University "University") in other
Commonwealth countries. There are also many non-official associations that
bring together individuals who work within the spheres of law and government,
such as the Commonwealth Lawyers Association and the [Commonwealth
Parliamentary Association](/wiki/Commonwealth_Parliamentary_Association
"Commonwealth Parliamentary Association").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### Commonwealth
Foundation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=30
"Edit section: Commonwealth Foundation")]

Main article: [Commonwealth Foundation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Foundation
"Commonwealth Foundation")

The [Commonwealth Foundation](/wiki/Commonwealth_Foundation "Commonwealth
Foundation") is an intergovernmental organisation, resourced by and reporting
to Commonwealth governments, and guided by Commonwealth values and priorities.
Its mandate is to strengthen civil society in the achievement of Commonwealth
priorities: democracy and good governance, respect for human rights and gender
equality, poverty eradication, people-centred and sustainable development, and
to promote arts and culture.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The Foundation was established in 1965 by the [Heads of
Government](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government "Commonwealth Heads of
Government"). Admittance is open to all members of the Commonwealth, and in
December 2008, stood at 46 out of the 53 member countries. Associate
Membership, which is open to associated states or overseas territories of
member governments, has been granted to Gibraltar. 2005 saw celebrations for
the Foundation's 40th Anniversary. The Foundation is headquartered in
[Marlborough House](/wiki/Marlborough_House "Marlborough House"), [Pall Mall,
London](/wiki/Pall_Mall,_London "Pall Mall, London"). Regular liaison and co-
operation between the Secretariat and the Foundation is in place. The
Foundation continues to serve the broad purposes for which it was established
as written in the Memorandum of Understanding.[133]

### Commonwealth
Games[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=31
"Edit section: Commonwealth Games")]

Main article: [Commonwealth Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth
Games")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Rugby_melbourne_commonwealth_games.jpg/220px-
Rugby_melbourne_commonwealth_games.jpg)](/wiki/File:Rugby_melbourne_commonwealth_games.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Rugby_melbourne_commonwealth_games.jpg "Enlarge")

The Commonwealth Games are the third-largest multi-sport event in the world,
bringing together globally popular sports and peculiarly "Commonwealth"
sports, such as [rugby sevens](/wiki/Rugby_sevens "Rugby sevens"), shown here
at the [2006 Games](/wiki/2006_Commonwealth_Games "2006 Commonwealth Games").

The [Commonwealth Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games"), a
[multi-sport event](/wiki/Multi-sport_event "Multi-sport event"), is held
every four years; the [2014 Commonwealth Games](/wiki/2014_Commonwealth_Games
"2014 Commonwealth Games") were held in [Glasgow,
Scotland](/wiki/Glasgow,_Scotland "Glasgow, Scotland"), and the [2018
Commonwealth Games](/wiki/2018_Commonwealth_Games "2018 Commonwealth Games")
in [Gold Coast, Australia](/wiki/Gold_Coast,_Queensland "Gold Coast,
Queensland"). [Birmingham](/wiki/Birmingham "Birmingham") is set to be the
host for [2022 Commonwealth Games](/wiki/2022_Commonwealth_Games "2022
Commonwealth Games"). As well as the usual athletic disciplines, as at the
[Summer Olympic Games](/wiki/Summer_Olympic_Games "Summer Olympic Games"), the
games include sports particularly popular in the Commonwealth, such as
[bowls](/wiki/Bowls "Bowls"), [netball](/wiki/Netball "Netball"), and [rugby
sevens](/wiki/Rugby_sevens "Rugby sevens"). Started in 1930 as the Empire
Games, the games were founded on the Olympic model of
[amateurism](/wiki/Amateurism "Amateurism"), but were deliberately designed to
be "the Friendly Games",[134] with the goal of promoting relations between
Commonwealth countries and celebrating their shared sporting and cultural
heritage.[135]

The games are the Commonwealth's most visible activity[134] and interest in
the operation of the Commonwealth increases greatly when the Games are
held.[136] There is controversy over whether the games—and sport
generally—should be involved in the Commonwealth's wider political
concerns.[135] The 1977 [Gleneagles Agreement](/wiki/Gleneagles_Agreement
"Gleneagles Agreement") was signed to commit Commonwealth countries to combat
[apartheid](/wiki/Apartheid "Apartheid") through discouraging sporting contact
with [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") (which was not then a
member), whilst the [1986 games](/wiki/1986_Commonwealth_Games "1986
Commonwealth Games") were boycotted by most African, Asian, and Caribbean
countries for the failure of other countries to enforce the Gleneagles
Agreement.[137]

### Commonwealth War Graves
Commission[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=32
"Edit section: Commonwealth War Graves Commission")]

Main article: [Commonwealth War Graves
Commission](/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission "Commonwealth War Graves
Commission")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b1/Azmak_Cemetery%2C_Gallipoli_Peninsula.JPG/220px-
Azmak_Cemetery%2C_Gallipoli_Peninsula.JPG)](/wiki/File:Azmak_Cemetery,_Gallipoli_Peninsula.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Azmak_Cemetery,_Gallipoli_Peninsula.JPG "Enlarge")

The [Commonwealth War Graves
Commission](/wiki/Commonwealth_War_Graves_Commission "Commonwealth War Graves
Commission") serves to commemorate 1.7 million Commonwealth war dead and
maintains 2,500 war cemeteries around the world, including this one in
[Gallipoli](/wiki/Gallipoli "Gallipoli").

The Commonwealth War Graves Commission (CWGC) is responsible for maintaining
the [war graves](/wiki/War_grave "War grave") of 1.7 million service personnel
that died in the First and Second World Wars fighting for Commonwealth member
states. Founded in 1917 (as the Imperial War Graves Commission), the
Commission has constructed 2,500 [war cemeteries](/wiki/War_cemetery "War
cemetery"), and maintains individual graves at another 20,000 sites around the
world.[138] The vast majority of the latter are civilian cemeteries in Great
Britain. In 1998, the CWGC made the records of its buried online to facilitate
easier searching.[139]

Commonwealth war cemeteries often feature similar
[horticulture](/wiki/Horticulture "Horticulture") and architecture, with
larger cemeteries being home to a [Cross of
Sacrifice](/wiki/Cross_of_Sacrifice "Cross of Sacrifice") and [Stone of
Remembrance](/wiki/Stone_of_Remembrance "Stone of Remembrance"). The CWGC is
notable for marking the graves identically, regardless of the rank, country of
origin, race, or religion of the buried.[139] It is funded by voluntary
agreement by six Commonwealth members, in proportion to the nationality of the
casualties in the graves maintained,[138] with 75% of the funding coming from
Britain.[139]

### Commonwealth of
Learning[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=33
"Edit section: Commonwealth of Learning")]

Main article: [Commonwealth of Learning](/wiki/Commonwealth_of_Learning
"Commonwealth of Learning")

The Commonwealth of Learning (COL) is an intergovernmental organisation
created by the [Heads of Government](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government
"Commonwealth Heads of Government") to encourage the development and sharing
of open learning/distance education knowledge, resources and technologies. COL
is helping developing nations improve access to quality education and
training.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

### The Commonwealth Local Government
Forum[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=34
"Edit section: The Commonwealth Local Government Forum")]

Main article: [Commonwealth Local Government
Forum](/wiki/Commonwealth_Local_Government_Forum "Commonwealth Local
Government Forum")

The Commonwealth Local Government Forum (CLGF) is a global local government
organisation, bringing together local authorities, their national associations
and the ministries responsible for local government in the member countries of
the Commonwealth. CLGF works with national and [local
governments](/wiki/Local_government "Local government") to support the
development of [democratic values](/wiki/Democracy "Democracy") and good local
governance and is the associated organisation officially recognised by
[Commonwealth Heads of Government](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government
"Commonwealth Heads of Government") as the representative body for local
government in the Commonwealth.[140]

CLGF is unique in bringing together central, provincial and local spheres of
government involved in local government policy and decision-making. CLGF
members include local government associations, individual local authorities,
ministries dealing with local government, and research and professional
organisations who work with local government. Practitioner to practitioner
support is at the core of CLGF's work across the Commonwealth and within the
region, using CLGF's own members to support others both within and between
regions. CLGF is a member of the Global Taskforce of Local and Regional
Governments, the formal partner of the UN Major Group of Local
Authorities.[141]

##
Culture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=35
"Edit section: Culture")]

Many Commonwealth nations possess traditions and customs that are elements of
a shared Commonwealth culture. Examples include common sports such as
[cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket") and [rugby](/wiki/Rugby_football "Rugby
football"), [driving on the left](/wiki/Driving_on_the_left "Driving on the
left"), the [Westminster system](/wiki/Westminster_system "Westminster
system") of [parliamentary democracy](/wiki/Parliamentary_democracy
"Parliamentary democracy"), [common law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law"),
[widespread use of the English language](/wiki/List_of_countries_by_English-
speaking_population "List of countries by English-speaking population"),
[designation of English as an official
language](/wiki/List_of_countries_where_English_is_an_official_language "List
of countries where English is an official language"), [military and naval
ranks](/wiki/Military_rank "Military rank"), and the use of British rather
than American spelling conventions (see [English in the Commonwealth of
Nations](/wiki/English_in_the_Commonwealth_of_Nations "English in the
Commonwealth of Nations")).[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Sport[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=36
"Edit section: Sport")]

Many Commonwealth nations play similar [sports](/wiki/Sports "Sports") that
are considered quintessentially British in character, rooted in and developed
under British rule or hegemony, including
[football](/wiki/Association_football "Association football"),
[cricket](/wiki/Cricket "Cricket"), [rugby](/wiki/Rugby_football "Rugby
football"), and [netball](/wiki/Netball "Netball").[142] This has led to the
development of friendly national rivalries between the main sporting nations
that have often defined their relations with each another. Indeed, said
rivalries preserved close ties by providing a constant in international
relationships, even as the Empire transformed into the Commonwealth.[143]
Externally, playing these sports is seen to be a sign of sharing a certain
Commonwealth culture; the adoption of [cricket at schools in
Rwanda](/wiki/Rwanda_Cricket_Association "Rwanda Cricket Association") is seen
as symbolic of the country's move towards Commonwealth membership.[144][145]

Besides the [Commonwealth Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth
Games"), other sporting competitions are organised on a Commonwealth basis,
through championship tournaments such as the [Commonwealth Taekwondo
Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Taekwondo_Championships "Commonwealth
Taekwondo Championships"), [Commonwealth Fencing
Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Fencing_Championships "Commonwealth Fencing
Championships"), [Commonwealth Judo
Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Judo_Championships "Commonwealth Judo
Championships"), [Commonwealth Rowing
Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Rowing_Championships "Commonwealth Rowing
Championships"), [Commonwealth Sailing
Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Sailing_Championships "Commonwealth Sailing
Championships"), [Commonwealth Shooting
Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Shooting_Championships "Commonwealth
Shooting Championships") and [Commonwealth Pool Lifesaving
Championships](/wiki/Commonwealth_Pool_Lifesaving_Championships "Commonwealth
Pool Lifesaving Championships"). The [Commonwealth Boxing
Council](/wiki/Commonwealth_Boxing_Council "Commonwealth Boxing Council") has
long maintained Commonwealth titles for the best boxers in the
Commonwealth.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

###
Literature[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=37
"Edit section: Literature")]

See also: [Postcolonial literature](/wiki/Postcolonial_literature
"Postcolonial literature") and [Migrant literature](/wiki/Migrant_literature
"Migrant literature")

The shared history of British presence has produced a substantial body of
writing in many languages, known as Commonwealth literature.[146][147] The
Association for Commonwealth Literature and Language Studies, with nine
chapters worldwide and an international conference is held every three
years.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_]

#### English as official
language[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=38
"Edit section: English as official language")]

In 1987, the Commonwealth Foundation established the annual [Commonwealth
Writers' Prize](/wiki/Commonwealth_Writers%27_Prize "Commonwealth Writers'
Prize") "to encourage and reward the upsurge of new Commonwealth fiction and
ensure that works of merit reach a wider audience outside their country of
origin". Prizes are awarded for the best book and best first book in the
Commonwealth, as well as regional prizes for the best book and best first book
from each of four regions. Although not officially affiliated with the
Commonwealth, the prestigious annual [Man Booker Prize](/wiki/Booker_Prize
"Booker Prize"), one of the highest honours in literature,[148] used to be
awarded only to authors from Commonwealth countries or former members such as
[Ireland](/wiki/Republic_of_Ireland "Republic of Ireland") and
[Zimbabwe](/wiki/Zimbabwe "Zimbabwe"). Since 2014, however, writers of any
nationality have been eligible for the prize providing that they write
originally in English and their novels are published by established publishers
in the United Kingdom[149] From 1950 on a significant number of writers from
the countries of the Commonwealth of Nations began gaining international
recognition, including some who migrated to the [United
Kingdom](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom"). There had been a few
important works in English prior to 1950 from the then [British
Empire](/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire"). The [South African
writer](/wiki/South_African_literature "South African literature") [Olive
Schreiner](/wiki/Olive_Schreiner "Olive Schreiner")'s famous novel _[The Story
of an African Farm](/wiki/The_Story_of_an_African_Farm "The Story of an
African Farm")_ was published in 1883 and [New
Zealander](/wiki/New_Zealand_literature "New Zealand literature") [Katherine
Mansfield](/wiki/Katherine_Mansfield "Katherine Mansfield") published her
first collection of short stories, _In a German Pension_ , in 1911. The first
major novelist, writing in English, from the [Indian sub-
continent](/wiki/Indian_English_literature "Indian English literature"), [R.
K. Narayan](/wiki/R._K._Narayan "R. K. Narayan"), began publishing in England
in the 1930s, thanks to the encouragement of English novelist [Graham
Greene](/wiki/Graham_Greene "Graham Greene").[150] [Caribbean
writer](/wiki/Caribbean_literature "Caribbean literature") [Jean
Rhys](/wiki/Jean_Rhys "Jean Rhys")'s writing career began as early as 1928,
though her most famous work, _[Wide Sargasso Sea](/wiki/Wide_Sargasso_Sea
"Wide Sargasso Sea")_ , was not published until 1966. South Africa's [Alan
Paton](/wiki/Alan_Paton "Alan Paton")'s famous _[Cry, the Beloved
Country](/wiki/Cry,_the_Beloved_Country "Cry, the Beloved Country")_ dates
from 1948. [Doris Lessing](/wiki/Doris_Lessing "Doris Lessing") from [Southern
Rhodesia](/wiki/Southern_Rhodesia "Southern Rhodesia"), now
[Zimbabwe](/wiki/Zimbabwe "Zimbabwe"), was a dominant presence in the English
literary scene, frequently publishing from 1950 on throughout the 20th
century. She won the [Nobel Prize in
Literature](/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature "Nobel Prize in Literature") in
2007.[151]

[Salman Rushdie](/wiki/Salman_Rushdie "Salman Rushdie") is another post Second
World War writer from the former British colonies who [permanently settled in
Britain](/wiki/Migrant_literature "Migrant literature"). Rushdie achieved fame
with _[Midnight's Children](/wiki/Midnight%27s_Children "Midnight's
Children")_ 1981\. His most controversial novel _[The Satanic
Verses](/wiki/The_Satanic_Verses "The Satanic Verses")_ 1989, was inspired in
part by the life of Muhammad. [V. S. Naipaul](/wiki/V._S._Naipaul "V. S.
Naipaul") (born 1932), born in [Trinidad](/wiki/Trinidad "Trinidad"), was
another immigrant, who wrote among other things _[A Bend in the
River](/wiki/A_Bend_in_the_River "A Bend in the River")_ (1979). Naipaul won
the Nobel Prize in Literature.[152]

Many other Commonwealth writers have achieved an international reputation for
works in English, including [Nigerian](/wiki/Nigerian_literature "Nigerian
literature") novelist [Chinua Achebe](/wiki/Chinua_Achebe "Chinua Achebe"),
and playwright [Wole Soyinka](/wiki/Wole_Soyinka "Wole Soyinka"). Soyinka won
the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1986, as did [South
African](/wiki/South_Africa "South Africa") novelist [Nadine
Gordimer](/wiki/Nadine_Gordimer "Nadine Gordimer") in 1995. Other South
African writers in English are novelist [J.M. Coetzee](/wiki/J.M._Coetzee
"J.M. Coetzee") (Nobel Prize 2003) and playwright [Athol
Fugard](/wiki/Athol_Fugard "Athol Fugard"). [Kenya](/wiki/Kenyan_literature
"Kenyan literature")'s most internationally renowned author is [Ngũgĩ wa
Thiong'o](/wiki/Ng%C5%A9g%C4%A9_wa_Thiong%27o "Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o") who has
written novels, plays and short stories in English. Poet [Derek
Walcott](/wiki/Derek_Walcott "Derek Walcott"), from [Saint
Lucia](/wiki/Saint_Lucia "Saint Lucia") in the Caribbean, was another Nobel
Prize winner in 1992. An [Australian](/wiki/Australian_literature "Australian
literature") [Patrick White](/wiki/Patrick_White "Patrick White"), a major
novelist in this period, whose first work was published in 1939, won in 1973.
Other noteworthy Australian writers at the end of this period are poet [Les
Murray](/wiki/Les_Murray_\(poet\) "Les Murray \(poet\)"), and novelist [Peter
Carey](/wiki/Peter_Carey_\(novelist\) "Peter Carey \(novelist\)"), who is one
of only four writers to have won the [Booker Prize](/wiki/Man_Booker_Prize
"Man Booker Prize") twice.[153]

### Political
system[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=39
"Edit section: Political system")]

Due to their shared constitutional histories, several countries in the
Commonwealth have similar legal and political systems. The Commonwealth
requires its members to be functioning democracies that respect [human
rights](/wiki/Human_rights "Human rights") and the [rule of
law](/wiki/Rule_of_law "Rule of law"). Most Commonwealth countries have the
bicameral [Westminster system](/wiki/Westminster_system "Westminster system")
of [parliamentary](/wiki/Parliamentary_system "Parliamentary system")
democracy. The [Commonwealth Parliamentary
Association](/wiki/Commonwealth_Parliamentary_Association "Commonwealth
Parliamentary Association") facilitates co-operation between legislatures
across the Commonwealth, and the [Commonwealth Local Government
Forum](/wiki/Commonwealth_Local_Government_Forum "Commonwealth Local
Government Forum") promotes [good governance](/wiki/Good_governance "Good
governance") amongst [local government](/wiki/Local_government "Local
government") officials. Most Commonwealth members use [common
law](/wiki/Common_law "Common law"), modelled on [English
law](/wiki/English_law "English law"). The [Judicial Committee of the Privy
Council](/wiki/Judicial_Committee_of_the_Privy_Council "Judicial Committee of
the Privy Council") is the [supreme court](/wiki/Supreme_court "Supreme
court") of 14 Commonwealth members.[154]

###
Symbols[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=40
"Edit section: Symbols")]

The Commonwealth has adopted a number of symbols that represent the
association of its members. The English language is recognised as a symbol of
the members' heritage; as well as being considered a symbol of the
Commonwealth, recognition of it as "the means of Commonwealth communication"
is a prerequisite for Commonwealth membership. The [flag of the
Commonwealth](/wiki/Flag_of_the_Commonwealth "Flag of the Commonwealth")
consists of the symbol of the Commonwealth Secretariat, a gold globe
surrounded by emanating rays, on a dark blue field; it was designed for the
[second CHOGM](/wiki/Commonwealth_Heads_of_Government_Meeting_1973
"Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting 1973") in 1973, and officially
adopted on 26 March 1976. 1976 also saw the organisation agree to a common
date on which to commemorate [Commonwealth Day](/wiki/Commonwealth_Day
"Commonwealth Day"), the second Monday in March, having developed separately
on different dates from [Empire Day](/wiki/Empire_Day "Empire Day")
celebrations.[155]

###
Recognition[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=41
"Edit section: Recognition")]

In 2009, to mark the 60th anniversary of the founding of the Commonwealth, the
[Royal Commonwealth Society](/wiki/Royal_Commonwealth_Society "Royal
Commonwealth Society") commissioned a poll of public opinion in seven of the
member states: Australia, Canada, India, Jamaica, Malaysia, South Africa and
the United Kingdom. It found that most people in these countries were largely
ignorant of the Commonwealth's activities, aside from the [Commonwealth
Games](/wiki/Commonwealth_Games "Commonwealth Games"), and indifferent toward
its future. Support for the Commonwealth was twice as high in developing
countries as in developed countries; it was lowest in Great
Britain.[156][157][158][159]

### Commonwealth
Anthem[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Commonwealth_of_Nations&action=edit&section=42
"Edit section: Commonwealth Anthem")]

Also to mark the 60th anniversary (Diamond Jubilee) of the Commonwealth in
2009, the Commonwealth Secretariat commissioned Paul Carroll to compose “The
Commonwealth Anthem”. The lyrics of the Anthem are taken from the 1948
[Universal Declaration of Human
Rights](/wiki/Universal_Declaration_of_Human_Rights "Universal Declaration of
Human Rights").[160] The Commonwealth has published the Anthem, performed by
the Commonwealth Youth Orchestra, with and without an introductory
narrative.[161][162]
